text:
[Starter]: Do you have any pets? How long have you had them, and what do you like most about them?
[Student]: Theyre just ordinary things for anything else I know And he gave a little sigh of relief as his friend spoke the names of all sorts of animals in that part of South America
[Teacher]: , a place he had never seen but had read about in books and was fascinated by it. It seemed that for the most part, people had pets that were ordinary, like dogs and cats. But there was one pet that stood out as different: a capybara, a large rodent that was native to South America. The capybara was known for its size, its brown fur, and its ability to swim. It was a popular pet in some parts of the country, and some
[Student]: of the other races did not like being put under their feet when they saw these new friends at work digging up an unpainted clay pipe from a nearby spring or river in a great forest on the top of a big mountain ridge or cliff above where those who ran after could be sure they knew nothing about a waterfall nor whether they were alive or dead or alive or without landmarks or if they made short journeys through the forest and over the forests near enough to find food to feed on

The story is about the bear that has been living in the forest on a mountain ridge above a river and spring which is filled with water that the animals in the forest would be eager to drink from.  The river is a place where many animals go to drink from and to take a bath and cool off as the summer sun beats down on them. text:
[Starter]: Do you enjoy cooking at home? What's the best meal you've made recently, or do you prefer eating out?
[Student]: Forget it all
